title: Éden (Eden)
transcript:
JAMES RONDEAU: You have Tropicália on the one hand as this very complex environment and then you have the work of art that really is developed as its mate, called Eden. So this is actually a work that is a second portrait of Brazil but this one made actually from the perspective outside of the nation. He described Tropicalia as a journey, and Eden as a destination.

NARRATOR: Like Tropicália, visitors are encouraged to become participants within Eden. Oiticica imagined visitors being able to relax in his artificial environment, reading magazines and books, engaging in a combination of passive leisure and active creativity.

JAMES RONDEAU: Helio develops a really wonderful word, an invented word, a neologism, where he smashes together two different words: creativity and leisure. And he calls it, “creleisure.” Creative resting. And there’s some kind of notion here that when you arrive into Eden, you’ve arrived at a place of rest. And that’s also one of most powerful sculptural innovations that we can find in Eden, which are these places called simply “nests,” these rectangular enclosures that are body-sized, that invite you to lie down, to have a solitary, recumbent experience, and to rest. You can replenish yourself, but this idea of a rest that also implies a powerful creativity. So, simply put, while you’re laying back, doing nothing, you’re participating in a creative act.
